required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Etiology of Early Apical Peri-implantitis: A Case-control Study Over a 20-year Period.

brief_summary.textblock: A case-control study was performed was performed following the STROBE statement from 1996 to 2016 including patients who were diagnosed with early apical peri-implantitis. Data were collected at the time of implant placement, and once the patients developed signs and symptoms consistent with early apical peri-implantitis, to determine the frequency and etiology of this pathology.

detailed_description.textblock:
A case-control study was performed following the STROBE statement (17) at the Oral Surgery Department, Faculty of Medicine and Dentistry (University of Valencia, Spain) from 1996 to 2016, in which patients with early peri-implantitis diagnosed were included (Figure 1). All patients were informed about the study design and procedures. Prior to participating, they were requested to sign an informed consent document. The study design was approved by the Ethical Committee of the University of Valencia (H1478255958653).
Two groups were established: Test group (patients diagnosed with early apical peri-implantitis diagnosed) and Control group (patients whose implants had not developed any inflammatory/infectious process and were osseointegrated).

primary_outcome.description: mesial and distal tooth-implant distance measured at the apex
apical lesion or endodontic treatment in the tooth being replaced or adjacent tooth endodontically treated

arm_group.description: Test group (patients diagnosed with early apical peri-implantitis diagnosed)
Control group (patients whose implants had not developed any inflammatory/infectious process and were osseointegrated)

intervention.intervention_name: Observational intervention to diagnose an early apical peri-implantitis

study_pop.textblock: patients who received at least one dental implant

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- The following inclusion criteria were applied: patients ≥18 years old and controlled medical conditions who received treatment with implants. Additionally, for the test group, inclusion criteria were: symptoms and signs suggesting early apical peri-implantitis after implant placement; absence of implant mobility; dull percussion of nonsurmerged implants; presence or absence of radiolucency apically.
Exclusion Criteria:
- for the both groups: implants placed with guided bone regeneration or inadequate follow-up for failing to maintenance visits.

overall_official.last_name: Miguel Peñarrocha Diago, MD, MDM, PhD
overall_official.affiliation: Professor and Chairman of Oral Surgery and Implantology. Medical and Dental School, Universitat of València, Spain

overall_official.last_name: Juan Antonio Blaya Tárraga, DDS, MSc
overall_official.affiliation: Master of Oral Surgery and Implantology

reference.citation: Quirynen M, Gijbels F, Jacobs R. An infected jawbone site compromising successful osseointegration. Periodontol 2000. 2003;33:129-44. Review.

results_reference.citation: Lefever D, Van Assche N, Temmerman A, Teughels W, Quirynen M. Aetiology, microbiology and therapy of periapical lesions around oral implants: a retrospective analysis. J Clin Periodontol. 2013 Mar;40(3):296-302. doi: 10.1111/jcpe.12045. Epub 2012 Dec 27.
Peñarrocha-Diago M, Maestre-Ferrín L, Cervera-Ballester J, Peñarrocha-Oltra D. Implant periapical lesion: diagnosis and treatment. Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal. 2012 Nov 1;17(6):e1023-7.

Zhao D, Wu Y, Xu C, Zhang F. Immediate dental implant placement into infected vs. non-infected sockets: a meta-analysis. Clin Oral Implants Res. 2016 Oct;27(10):1290-1296. doi: 10.1111/clr.12739. Epub 2015 Dec 15.

clinical_study.keyword: "early apical peri-implantitis"; "implant periapical lesion"; "retrograde peri-implantitis"; "implant failure"
